title: Stats on digital policy instrument suite
body:
Blog to publish some statistics around the number of requirements that some senior officials are expected to be accountable for. Especially the CIO.

Puts emphasis on the role of the CIO in bringing digital to a reality.
That LOBs need to develop stronger technical acumen, and that IT staff need to foster stronger empathy towards their business counter parts (e.g. it's not always about code, it's about policy and preparing for changes coming up from those policy changes).

**NOTE 1**: footer.html changed _includes/footer.html to use an absolute reference to datatable.js (using site.baseurl) as I got errors from *.md files in a posts folder

**NOTE 2**: french translation will be pushed after peer review (and before merge)

milestone.title: Product Mgt - Do Research
milestone.description:
@remyb2canada Research governance materials (Financial, PM and Agile methodologies) to be better informed:

- CFOB's Directives on PM and Programme Management

- CFOB's tool suites (limitations like reporting that shapes behaviours)

- The Delicate Art of Bureaucracy

body:
Provide with a synthesis of where IITB spends its limited funds (salary and non-salary): A-Base funding

- [ ] Musts (e.g. licence renewal, SSC yearly contributions, mission critical IT services (?))
- [ ] Salary distribution (keep the lights on vs Projects)
- [ ] List of ESDC Critical Systems (Based on BCP BIA and APM+)

Then identify:
- [ ] where it never changes year over year
- [ ] where we sustain critical systems, with track record of predictable funding allocation, prioritization
- [ ] where demand is vs where major costs are

Purpose: discover where internal capacity could be released to perform more meaningful work (hypothesis: mission critical systems are always in demand but we spend unecessary bureaucratic process to formalize this engagement when historical track records show predictable approval and funding, therefore producing waste)

title: Blog on "Team understanding of the digital transformation"
body:
I cut this content from the Mandate page of our website and liked the idea of making this topic a separate blog. 


### **Team understanding of the "digital transformation"**

IT is now used to deliver services to Canadians.
If IT fails, the business fails and vice versa.
The use of technology is no longer "an IT problem" as it has real repercussions to citizens.
IT can no longer be seen as a company within another company (or an outside supplier), it has shared accountability with the organization's mandate and is a strategic asset.

Current IT processes and governance methods are risky and costly, which translates into a long time to deliver or change applications, devices and support.
Recovering from incidents is hard and errors resulting from changes are frequent.
We must reduce risks associated with IT and continuously improve in all of its areas.

That is **Digital Transformation**.

It's an ongoing venture due to the rapid pace of change in the IT world.
It has no end date.
It never ends.

title: IT Strategy team - reporting

milestone.title: Team's own Continuous Improvement
milestone.description: Various tasks to improve the team's effectiveness, relationship with other stakeholders, awareness, etc.

body:
**Known reporting needs:**
_Regular:_
- Weekly report to Senior Director: excel spreadsheet report populated manually by manager based on info in the Kanban board. Each team reporting to the senior director has their own tab. On the IT Strategy tab there is one row for each the team's main deliverables. Report data includes: project/deliverable name, start date, end date, names of the main team members working on that project/deliverable, then a free text field listing updates on that item of relevance to the SD. Note this report is currently under review (opportunity to influence?). As part of the changes from this review the start and end dates are expected to change from dates to quarters
- Monthly reporting for lite projects: Only required for the micro-acquisition pilot (assuming it gets approved). Still learning about these requirements but it looks like for each lite project, monthly updates are required on: all financials, expected completion date and red/yellow/green for health, scope, cost, sched, risks, issues. Preliminary investigations indicate that this information is pulled from PMIS which we will have to update manually.
- MAF: yearly? unknown information/granularity requirements

_Ad hoc:_
- The roadmap (from the planning powerpoint file) was provided as part of the briefing binder for the new DG. It visually depicts each of the team's main deliverables showing the start/end (time to complete). This is a high level report with no detailed activity information.
- acting DG requested a report showing what the team was working on for the 'next few months'. High level report was provided. Not sure exactly what data was in the report

**Unknown reporting needs:**
Yep. ;-)

**Other points to note:**
- reporting required for the micro-acquisition project may need to be to a greater level due to the anticipated scrutiny that could come from being high profile.
- need to translate what we are doing into reportable chunks (that fit in with departmental reporting)
- need to demonstrate team value/PR
- more granular more options?

title: Blog - loose coupling for the non-techie
body:
A blog that seeks to explain the loose coupling principle using a document analogy. For non-technical audience.

- PDF document: the published version meant for public consumption.
- Word document: the un-published version, meant for the policy writers working on it together.

The larger the Word document, the more complex it is to coordinate the writers when it is being updated, the more it can create bottlenecks when trying to publish a PDF version (e.g. stopping writers from updating it so we can publish a version).

Breaking down large documents into smaller ones is loose coupling. Each potentially publishable on their own instead of aggregating into a large volume.

Complexity of managing multiple documents is warranted so that we can more quickly publish updates.

MAY ( depending on length of blog) touch the idea that your fancy text formatting in the word document is just presentation. The information is the raw text. MS Word is just a tool helping you to format and write your information.

title: Blog: What companies to follow
body:
Depts often look to banks, or insurance companies, or other governments to learn from -- which isn't the best approach. Project to Product (~pg 187 on Kindle) & Gene Kims podcast (episode 2 & 3) discuss the idea that each "revolution" (ex: industrial) follows the same pattern. Some companies learn how best to leverage the new technology and become hugely successful. Then companies learn from these successes, and begin implementing the lessons of the success stories (the distribution phase, or some such thing). Companies that do not learn from the vangaurd companies fail.

Conclusion: We should be learning from those who have mastered the new technologies, not looking to other companies struggling to keep up to generate/derive our own direction

title: Blog post explaining the terms Cloud (public, private), on prem, hybrid
PROPOSAL - Presentation that visualizes Loose Coupling Architecture
body:
_Goal_: Produce a presentation for ARC and SLF on what it means to do Loose Coupling Architecture 

_Purpose_: Inform and Educate the audience on the **rapid elasticity** capability of cloud technologies and the compromise of increased data management complexity (e.g. micro services) for a greater autonomy to IT Products / Teams

_This idea's background_: After peer reviewing the Target IT Solution Delivery Model, hearing the interoperability team struggle in convincing others to move towards APIs and use of containers, I get the impression that loose coupling is misunderstood or simply not believed in. E.g. "I get loose coupling, but no IT product can be independent from each other. You will always have dependencies.". This may be true in a legacy environment that is Monolith in nature and cannot rapidly scale but in with cloud technologies and proper data management capabilities (e.g. event based messaging, caching, synchronization) it can be.

_Topics to cover in the presentation_: 
 - Demystify Loose Coupling. IT Products **can** run independently in production. Even if those IT Products get their data from a other source (e.g. PeopleSoft get their data from Phoenix. When Phoenix goes down, PeopleSodt keeps running).
 - Accept greater data management complexity. Data will be duplicated and distributed. This tradeoff to allow more autonomy and speed for change. 
 - Rapid Elasticity of cloud allows IT products to scale, on demand, to supply requests in a timely manner
 - Caching capabilities are expected to reduce latency 

_Needs Contributions from_:
 - Solutions Architecture team (member of ARC)
 - Interopery team (member of ARC, and QA for APIs to be published on the GC API store)
 - Cloud CoE (for support and credibility if we talk Cloud)
 - CDO (because data management)

milestone.description: Various tasks to improve the team's effectiveness, relationship with other stakeholders, awareness, etc.

body:
**Problem Statement**
As part of the IT Strategy team, it is difficult to fully comprehend the pain points and challenges other IT teams are facing. E.g. mainframes, testing, IT Security, operations of specialized environments or legacy servers. 

At the Enterprise Ops DG extended management meeting, it was suggested that IT Strategy team members come and shadow personnel of teams to better comprehend their daily lives.

**Proposal**

Create a new milestone with the goal of coordinating micro missions throughout IITB for the IT Strategy team members. Format to be discussed but could take the form of:

- IT Strategy team members all go on micro missions for 1 week, every 3 months
- members report back after 1 week to debrief the rest of the team

The milestone is to identify IT teams to shadow, seek buy-in from their managers/directors, and coordinate the timing of the micromissions

title: PROPOSAL - new milestone to Build the SEED/SKILLZ Inventory app
body:
_Problem Statement_

IITB HR had a problem called "SEED" where employees could upload their resumes as a means to broadcast their skillsets and aspirations. This would then let IITB managers a way to find expertise, making it easier to allow micro-missions, and allow employees greater mobility and exposure.

The current program doesn't seem to be automated enough where HR no longer had the capacity to support it. It may not have been adequately broadcasted enough, or intuitive as well to be fully used.

At first, it sounds similar to the [GCConnex Career Marketplace](https://gcconnex.gc.ca/missions/main). 

_Proposal_

- Evaluate IITB HR's SEED program with that of [GCConnex Career Marketplace](https://gcconnex.gc.ca/missions/main) for similarities and gaps (to justify whether to use GCConnex or not)
- Build a SEED web application to sustain the SEED program without administrative burdens and make it intuitive for users (managers and employees)

title: Blog - Software is not a physical asset
body: Following blog post #469 , I'd like to dive deeper into why software should no longer be managed as a physical asset. It is mentioned in the previous blog post but I think a full post in that concept is required to better explain what we mean.

title: Blog - We are not in the software business

milestone.title: Team's own Continuous Improvement
milestone.description: Various tasks to improve the team's effectiveness, relationship with other stakeholders, awareness, etc.

body:
Following blog post #469 , I'd like us to tackle the saying that Government is not in the software business, a recurring theme where we should not develop software but rather have private sector bid in offering us their commoditized solutions.

Key concepts:
- Software is not a building
 - As stated in previous blog, we have been building houses and large building for centuries and have acquired a know-how
 - But even if information technology is a relatively new concept that evolves at an increasingly higher speed, the real differentiator with the skyscraper analogy is that software is intangible, immaterial.
 - Large informations systems are definitely complicated but given our methods of governance based on managing physical assets, we don't reap the full benefits of this intangible nature of software.
- Software is the executable version (compiled/interpreted) of the program's source code which in turn is the translation of an algorithm written in human readable language into a structured language. An algorithm is a series of reproducible steps, a process...
- Governments are bureaucratic organizations, putting in place policies, directives and guidelines in line with laws and programs developed by elected officials, then establishing and continuously improving processes to ensure expectable results to apply said programs and laws. They are essentially designing algorithms.
- When someone says that Government is not in the software business, what is meant by that is that we are not meant to build software but rather offer citizens services. The software should be bought from software companies.

Argument: 
Government is not in the software business, it is in the business of offering vital services to its citizens, driven by the democratic process. However, in order to provide services to citizens, Government now needs to be able to design and build software solutions as a way to meet the needs of its citizens that now live in a Digital world, no matter where they may be.

This requires platforms provided for all business lines, multidisciplinary teams that shift from project to products/services (see IT Picture Medium/Long term).

Procurement of commoditized software components is acceptable as long as said components are fully interoperable, interchangeable and can be executed on any runtime, whether that is a public cloud service provider or on-premise.

title: Blog - business rules are broken, not the system
body:
Blog about how with Digital Government, policy and delivery will use technology. This means that rules that were originally written in word documents will need to be written in machine readable AND execution formats. 

If the machine can't process them, it's not the machine that is the problem. It's the human that created that rule.

E.g. Phoenix system and the large amount of collective agreement rules that had to be programmed in

title: Blog - Create Working in the Open post with maths on Why?
body:
We can start with the following `why`:
- Discoverability
 - Probably simple: if workspace closed, amount of chances you can find info/reusable components == 0 :wink:
- Early feedback loop
 - DevOps Handbook provides some of the maths behind it, easier and a lot less risky to change elements on small batches than a fully "completed" product
- Economies of scale
 - If size of team = X, and capacity = C, any contribution (k) increases the total of work possible (T) beyond what you would have been able to accomplish to start with.
- Reduction of work duplication
 - Might be a bit trickier but still are a few key elements to consider: 
 - Time spent analysing, prioritizing, planning and trying to harness info of all possible work at department level inherently looks at each "proposal" from a tunnel vision view, potentially surfacing duplicate proposals but most of the time choosing one over the other instead of focussing on the potential features of each (product vs project). War & Peace & IT 
 - The current process is very tedious and time consuming, leading to ideas being dismissed
 - A project done in silo without reusability of its components in mind can lead to waste. (Also, if you procure a closed source product, it is managed as a physical good vs an open source software that has no limits on the number of use - it is intangible and thus can scale infinitely)

*Useful Referenced Materials*
- [DORA 2019 Report](http://dialogue/grp/BU6810070/Shared%20Documents/Reference%20Materials/DORA-state-of-devops-2019.pdf), page 57 on productivity
